unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Drawing Conclusions
question_text:
A hotel manager wishes to compare the number of guests she has per night to a competitor hotel's guests per night in town.
The manager records the number of guests staying per night during the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at her hotel and compares them to numbers for the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at the competitor.
The manager performs a two-sample $T$-Interval (her hotel - competitor’s hotel) and gets the values of $28.54$ to $32.56$ at $95\%$ confidence.
What could be a valid conclusion of this interval?

choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident the hotel manager has between $28.54$ and $32.56\text{ guests}$ per night at her hotel.
We are $95\%$ confident there are between $28.54$ and $32.56\text{ guests}$ per night at the competitor’s hotel.
There is evidence the manager’s hotel gets more guests than her competitor’s hotel, significant at the $5\%$ level.
We are $95\%$ confident there are between $28.54$ and $32.56$ more guests per night at the manager’s hotel than at the competitor’s hotel.

solution:
This correctly shows how to interpret a two-sample $T$-interval, estimating the difference.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'A' and 'B' are incorrect; a two-sample $T$-interval attempts to measure the difference between the two means, not a single mean.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Since this entire interval is above zero, there is evidence the manager’s hotel has more guests than the competitor’s, but one cannot say this is significant at the $5\%$ level because intervals are two-sided by nature, and the statement in (C) is one-sided.
